Reports claim that the sweetener aspartame, commonly found in various foods and fizzy drinks, is set to be officially classified as "possibly carcinogenic" to humans. However, the label "possibly carcinogenic" does not indicate the magnitude of the potential risk. Other substances classified as "possibly carcinogenic" include aloe vera, diesel, and pickled Asian vegetables. The International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) is expected to make an announcement on July 14th. Aspartame, which is 200 times sweeter than sugar, provides a sweet taste without the added calories. It is commonly found in diet drinks, chewing gums, and some yogurts. The sweetener has been in use for decades and has been approved by food safety bodies, but there has been controversy surrounding its safety.

The IARC, the cancer research arm of the World Health Organization, has been conducting a review of approximately 1,300 studies on aspartame and cancer. The Reuters news agency has reported that aspartame will be classified as "possibly carcinogenic." However, it is important to note that this classification does not indicate the actual level of risk associated with aspartame. The IARC classifications provide information on the strength of the evidence rather than the actual risk to health. The "possibly" category is used when there is limited evidence from human or animal studies. It is worth noting that substances categorized in this group do not have strong evidence suggesting they cause cancer.

The IARC classifications have been criticized in the past for causing confusion and unnecessary alarm. It is important to interpret these classifications correctly. The exact risk associated with aspartame is not provided in the data. The Joint World Health Organization and Food and Agriculture Organization's Expert Committee on Food Additives is expected to release a report in July, which may provide further information. Previous scientific committees have considered aspartame safe for consumption at current permitted use levels. Studies linking aspartame to cancer have been controversial, with conflicting results from animal and human studies. Aspartame is generally regarded as safe, except for individuals with an inherited condition called phenylketonuria (PKU), who cannot metabolize a component of aspartame.

Scientists have discovered a key defense mechanism that effectively blocks the majority of bird flu strains from invading our bodies. Bird flus have caused four pandemics since 1918, resulting in millions of deaths. Researchers from the University of Glasgow found that these pandemics, along with regular winter flus, have evolved strategies to bypass this natural defense barrier. The team believes that soon they will be able to predict which bird flu strains pose the greatest risk.

The scientists conducted investigations into spillover events, which occur when a person becomes infected by an animal. This cross-species transmission is a critical step in the emergence of a new pandemic. Through laboratory experiments, the researchers identified a specific section of our DNA called BTN3A3 that becomes activated in response to infection. BTN3A3 was found to be active in the nose, throat, and lungs, reducing the ability of bird flu strains to replicate.

Dr. Rute Maria Pinto, one of the researchers, stated that "nearly all" bird flu strains are unable to bypass this protective mechanism and therefore cannot infect humans. However, most human viruses, including pandemic strains, have evolved resistance to BTN3A3 and can overcome this defense barrier.

There is an ongoing risk of bird flu strains crossing over into humans, as wild birds harbor various flu viruses, and poultry poses a significant risk due to the large number of farmed animals in close proximity to humans. The 1918 flu pandemic, which is estimated to have caused 50 million deaths, is believed to have originated in birds. The researchers discovered that a specific bird flu strain called H7N9 developed higher resistance to BTN3A3 before the first human cases emerged in 2013.

The researchers envision a future where the genetic code of circulating bird flu strains can be routinely analyzed and dangerous strains identified. This knowledge would enable targeted measures to be implemented to control high-risk viruses. Prof Massimo Palmarini, director of the Centre for Virus Research in Glasgow, explained that sequencing the virus's genetic code would allow scientists to assess the likelihood of a virus crossing over to humans.

Regarding the current bird flu outbreak, the largest ever recorded, more than 50% of virus samples from birds and all seven human cases detected this year have shown resistance to BTN3A3. However, bypassing BTN3A3 is just one aspect of the virus's threat to human health, and other factors must be considered. Dr. Stephen Oakeshott from the Medical Research Council emphasized the importance of mechanistic scientific insights and genetic surveillance in understanding viral transmission between species and informing public health planning.

An appeal has been launched to raise one million pounds for the leukaemia treatment of a 20-month-old girl named Hallie from Coventry. Hallie was diagnosed with leukaemia at Birmingham Children's Hospital when she was eight months old. After her last stem cell transplant failed, her family was informed that their best option might be to seek treatment in the United States. Hallie's aunt, Hannah Dugdale, described it as a daunting task.

Hallie was first diagnosed with a rare form of leukaemia called JMML in the summer of 2022 while on a family vacation in Spain. She was flown back home for treatment and has since undergone chemotherapy, blood transfusions, and two stem cell transplants. On Thursday, the family learned that the latest transplant had not been successful, and a consultant at the Birmingham hospital suggested CAR T-cell therapy as their remaining option. CAR T-cell therapy involves genetically modifying immune system cells called T cells to enhance their effectiveness in targeting cancer cells, which are then reintroduced into the patient's bloodstream.

Although a trial for CAR T-cell therapy is scheduled to begin at Great Ormond Street Hospital in the coming months, Hallie's family prefers not to wait and hopes to take her to the United States for treatment. However, the third transplant required for the treatment is not funded by the National Health Service (NHS). Hallie's aunt expressed that her niece deserves every chance at a long and happy life and described her sister, Kim, as devastated but also grateful for the overwhelming support they have received. The fundraising appeal has already surpassed 180,000, and they hope to commence treatment before reaching the full amount through their Go Fund Me page.

Birmingham Children's Hospital stated that a third transplant is not a current treatment option for Hallie's rare form of leukaemia. However, the hospital's teams are actively exploring other possibilities for her, including the potential of experimental CAR T-cell therapy as part of a clinical trial. NHS England has been contacted for a response regarding the matter.

European Union (EU) officials are strongly recommending that all member states require negative Covid tests from Chinese arrivals before they travel, as travel in and out of China is set to become easier due to the scrapping of the "zero-Covid" policy. China is currently experiencing a surge in Covid cases, leading to overwhelmed hospitals and crematoriums.

Some EU countries have already implemented testing requirements, despite earlier advice suggesting it was unjustified. The EU's Integrated Political Crisis Response group (IPCR), comprised of officials from the EU's 27 governments, has recommended several measures. These include the wearing of face masks by all passengers on flights to and from China, the introduction of random testing for flights from China, and conducting wastewater monitoring at airports.

The European Commission has stated that a majority of member states favor restrictions on Chinese arrivals, leading to France, Spain, and Italy already implementing testing requirements. Germany has been monitoring the situation, while England, which is outside the EU, has mandated pre-flight testing for arrivals from China starting Thursday. It is unclear whether an EU-wide policy will be introduced, as individual states can determine their own policies.

The IPCR's recommendation represents a change in direction from the advice given by the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC) last week, which advised against mandatory Covid testing. The ECDC argued that testing was unnecessary due to high vaccination rates in Europe and the presence of variants circulating within the EU that originated from China.

The World Health Organization (WHO) stated that there is currently no evidence of new variants in China despite the surge in cases. However, experts have cautioned that this may be due to a lack of testing and data. The WHO has also noted that China has been underreporting the true impact of Covid in the country, partly because of a narrow definition of Covid-related deaths. Beijing has officially confirmed only 22 deaths since December, whereas analysts estimate much higher numbers, with over two million daily Covid cases and 14,700 deaths according to the UK science data company Airfinity.

The Chinese government has suggested that travel restrictions on Chinese arrivals are politically motivated and has warned of potential retaliation.

Experts have informed the BBC that the current surge of Covid cases in China is unlikely to impact India, but they emphasize the importance of remaining cautious and wearing masks.

India has increased surveillance following a spike in cases in neighboring China. Individuals traveling from China and four other Asian countries are now required to provide a negative Covid-19 test report before entering India. In preparation for a surge, drills were conducted to assess the capacity of hospitals.

According to government data, India currently has around 3,400 active coronavirus cases. However, reports of the surge in China and the memory of two deadly Covid waves in 2020 and 2021 have raised concerns among many people.

Experts reassure the public that there is no reason to worry at this moment. Dr. Chandrakant Lahariya, an epidemiologist and health systems specialist, explains that the surge in infections in China is expected when a susceptible population is not exposed to the virus. He emphasizes that nothing has changed for the rest of the world, including India.

China has been grappling with a surge in Covid cases after moving away from its previous "zero-Covid" approach, which involved strict lockdowns, quarantines, and closed borders. The country is now striving to accelerate vaccinations for its vulnerable elderly population as the surge strains healthcare systems. Some experts have raised concerns about whether the main vaccines used in China, Sinovac and Sinopharm, can provide long-term immunity.

Dr. Jacob John, a virologist, explains that people are getting infected because the Omicron subvariant known as BF.7, which is driving the surge in China, is highly infectious and can evade previous immunity. He notes that individuals without immunity are at greater risk, particularly the elderly and immunosuppressed populations.

India has reported four Covid-19 cases caused by BF.7 in recent months, and all patients have recovered, according to health officials. Dr. Lalit Kant, an epidemiologist, states that while Covid is still present, it has become similar to another upper respiratory tract infection like influenza.

The low caseload in India can be largely attributed to the immunity gained over the past three years. Dr. A Fathahudeen, a critical care expert, explains that India's "hybrid immunity wall" against Covid-19 is satisfactory, as a majority of people have either received two vaccine doses or gained natural immunity from prior infections. He also highlights that the vaccines used in India are more effective than those used in China.

To further enhance immunity, Dr. Fathahudeen recommends people to take the booster dose if they haven't already done so. Currently, only around 27% of the population has received the booster dose. Experts generally agree with this appeal and stress the benefits of receiving a third shot, particularly for individuals above 60 years of age and those at high risk.

The government's decision to increase genome sequencing, allowing for the identification of new variants, is also supported by experts. Dr. John states that the current testing strategy of random genome sequencing of 2% of international travelers is sufficient to detect any new variant.

Experts urge the government and individuals to adopt a mindset of expecting the best while preparing for the worst. They recommend wearing masks in crowded places, such as during sports events or on crowded buses and trains. Dr. John emphasizes the need for long-term, sustainable behavioral changes. Earlier this year, India relaxed its mask-wearing rules due to a decline in infection levels, but experts now advise caution and adherence to mask-wearing, especially in crowded areas.

In conclusion, experts advise the public to remain cautious, wear masks, and stay informed about the latest news regarding the Covid situation. They also discourage unnecessary crowding and suggest wearing masks when large gatherings cannot be avoided.

According to the World Health Organization (WHO), hospitals in China are reportedly filling up amid concerns of a new wave of Covid-19 hitting the country. Dr. Michael Ryan states that intensive care units (ICUs) are busy, despite officials claiming that case numbers are "relatively low". There is skepticism about the true impact of the disease, as China's figures show no Covid-related deaths on Wednesday. However, recent reports indicate that hospitals in Beijing and other cities have been experiencing a surge in admissions due to the latest Covid outbreak.

Since 2020, China has implemented strict health restrictions as part of its zero Covid policy. However, most of these measures were lifted two weeks ago after significant protests against the strict controls. Since then, the number of cases has sharply risen, raising concerns about the high mortality rate among the elderly, who are particularly vulnerable.

Despite the official figures indicating a low number of Covid deaths, WHO emergencies chief Dr. Ryan urges China to provide more information about the current spread of the virus. He notes that although reported ICU cases are low, there are anecdotal reports of ICUs filling up. The highly infectious nature of the virus makes it difficult to completely stop its spread through public health and social measures alone.

During a weekly news conference in Geneva, WHO chief Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus expresses his deep concern over the evolving situation in China. He calls for specific data on disease severity, hospital admissions, and intensive care requirements to be shared.

Dr. Ryan emphasizes that vaccination is the key strategy to combat coronavirus outbreaks. China has developed and produced its own vaccines, which have shown to be less effective in preventing serious Covid illness and death compared to mRNA vaccines used in other parts of the world.

In related news, the German government has announced that it sent its first batch of BioNTech Covid-19 vaccines to China. These vaccines will initially be administered to expats in China, estimated to be around 20,000 individuals. This marks the first delivery of a foreign Covid-19 vaccine to China, although no specific details have been released regarding the delivery size or timing. During a visit to Beijing, Chancellor Olaf Scholz had urged for the vaccine to be made freely available to Chinese citizens.

In the town of Taveta, located near the border with Tanzania in Kenya's Taita Hills, families gathered at a local health clinic. They were waiting to hear from Lea Kilenga Bey, who asked if anyone had sickle cell. In response, they all shouted that they either carry the genetic mutation or are caring for someone who does. Taveta, with a population of 22,000, has one of the highest rates of sickle cell disease in Kenya, affecting nearly one in four residents.

Sickle cell disease causes the red blood cells, which are normally round, to have a crescent or sickle shape. This leads to a reduced ability to transport oxygen throughout the body, resulting in severe pain episodes that can last for weeks. According to the World Health Organization (WHO), two-thirds of people affected by sickle cell worldwide live in African countries. It is the most prevalent genetically acquired disease in the region, and child mortality rates are high, with more than half of children born with sickle cell dying before the age of five.

Lea Kilenga Bey, who was diagnosed with sickle cell at six months old and is now in her 30s, founded the Africa Sickle Cell organization in 2017 to improve the lives of people with the disease. She returned to Taveta, her hometown, to raise awareness and dispel myths and misconceptions surrounding sickle cell, which some communities attribute to ancestral curses or witchcraft. Access to medicine is a major challenge for individuals with sickle cell in Taveta and other towns across Kenya. Daily treatment, including antibiotics, blood cell medications, and dietary supplements, is necessary for managing the disease. However, many people cannot afford the expensive medications and must choose between buying medicine or food.

Ms Bey has experienced sickle cell crises firsthand and recorded video diaries to raise awareness about the excruciating pain caused by the disease. In Taveta, she joined a group of people protesting at the local hospital, demanding better treatment and medication. Expired medicine and lack of proper medical care have led to the loss of lives in the community. As a result of advocacy efforts by Albert Loghwaru and Lea Kilenga Bey, a joint haemophilia and sickle clinic was established in Taveta, the first in Taita Taveta county. However, the struggle for better care and support for individuals with sickle cell continues.

Ms Bey emphasizes that their work has just begun, comparing it to a relay race rather than a marathon. The focus is on continuing efforts to improve the lives of people with sickle cell and ensure access to necessary treatment and support for the community.

A panel of US medical experts is recommending that women start preventative breast cancer screening a decade earlier than current guidelines suggest. They propose initiating mammograms at age 40 and having regular screenings every two years. The draft guidelines from the US Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) are currently undergoing review. Previous recommendations advised most women to begin screening at age 50.

The task force, composed of doctors and disease experts who evaluate research on disease prevention, claims that if the new recommendations are adopted, they could save the lives of an additional 19% of American women. Breast cancer is the second most common cancer among women in the United States, and nearly 13% of American women will receive a breast cancer diagnosis during their lifetime.

The new screening guidelines are particularly significant for black women, who are reported to be "40% more likely to die from breast cancer than white women," according to the task force's statement. Dr. Wanda Nicholson, Vice Chair of the USPSTF, emphasized that while ensuring black women start screening at age 40 is an important first step, it alone is insufficient to address the health disparities related to breast cancer.

The proposed draft guidelines are intended for women at average risk for breast cancer or those with a family history of the disease. They also include women with other risk factors, such as dense breast tissue, which can increase the risk of cancer and make it more challenging to detect using mammograms. However, these guidelines would not apply to women with a genetic risk of breast cancer, such as those carrying the BRCA1 genetic mutation.

Kristan Hawkins, the founder of Students for Life of America (SFLA), has become a prominent figure in the anti-abortion movement in the United States. She started her journey as an activist when she was 15, volunteering at a crisis pregnancy center and becoming deeply committed to the pro-life cause. Over the years, she has grown SFLA into one of the largest anti-abortion organizations in the country, with a focus on training and mobilizing young activists on college campuses.

Hawkins is known for her relentless dedication and unyielding approach. She played a significant role in the push for stricter abortion laws after the Supreme Court's decision to overturn Roe v. Wade. Under her leadership, SFLA has been instrumental in advocating for anti-abortion bills in various state legislatures. These efforts have led to the restriction or unavailability of abortion for millions of women, sparking public health concerns.

While Hawkins and her organization have been successful in advancing their agenda, they face opposition from pro-choice advocates and even some Republicans who believe their approach is extreme. Hawkins has set her sights on achieving a federal abortion ban, starting at conception, which goes against public opinion that generally supports access to legal abortion.

Hawkins' strategy of pushing for early abortion bans at six weeks of pregnancy reflects a departure from the incremental approach favored by other anti-abortion groups. Her outspokenness and refusal to compromise on exceptions for rape and incest, as well as her opposition to certain forms of birth control, have drawn criticism from both pro-choice activists and more moderate Republicans.

Despite the divisions within the anti-abortion movement and the political challenges ahead, Hawkins remains determined to pursue her goal. She is willing to challenge politicians who do not align with her strict pro-life stance and believes that the movement should continue to push for increasingly extreme measures in the absence of Roe v. Wade.

Hawkins' uncompromising approach has solidified her influence among anti-abortion activists, even as public opinion and electoral dynamics shift in favor of abortion rights. As the movement moves further to the right, she is seen as a driving force behind its shift toward more extreme abortion bans.

Since the US Supreme Court's Dobbs decision ended 50 years of protected access to abortions in the United States, parents of teens and preteens are finding themselves in the position of having to have more detailed conversations with their children about reproductive health and birth control. The changing legal landscape around reproductive healthcare has raised concerns and a sense of urgency among parents, who are now discussing topics such as renting out-of-state post office boxes, using public WiFi, and deleting personal details from phone apps to ensure privacy and avoid tracking.

One mother, referred to as Christine, expressed shock and concern after the Dobbs decision became official. She felt the need to protect her children and had discussions with her teenage son and his friend about the increased risks and responsibilities associated with sexual activity. Christine emphasized the potential need for funds to cover travel expenses for out-of-state abortions and stressed the importance of making responsible choices.

Another parent, Adam, and his wife in Louisiana, discussed birth control options for their 15-year-old daughter earlier than planned due to concerns about potential restrictions on birth control access. They decided to get their daughter an intrauterine device (IUD) to provide long-acting contraception. They felt that their choices had been limited and wanted to ensure their daughter's future was not derailed.

The changing landscape of reproductive health care also affects access for teens who cannot discuss birth control with their parents. Programs like Title X, which provide family planning services to low-income patients and adolescents, have been crucial in providing access to birth control. However, these programs are now under threat, leaving some teenagers with limited options.

In Texas, for example, minors need parental consent to access birth control, even if they are already parents themselves. Title X clinics used to provide free and confidential contraception, but a recent ruling deemed it a violation of parental rights and state law. This has further restricted access for teenagers in Texas.

The Dobbs decision and related changes in reproductive health care have led parents to engage in more open and direct discussions about sexual health with their children. They are taking proactive measures to ensure access to contraception and protect their children's future.

For the past decade, highly effective medications for hepatitis C have been available but have not been widely accessible in the United States, leading to significant disparities in treatment. These direct-acting antiviral drugs have been hailed as major medical breakthroughs, with a cure rate of 95% and minimal side effects. However, the high cost of these drugs, which were initially priced at around $90,000 for a course of treatment, has made them unaffordable for many patients.

A recent study published in the CDC's Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report highlights the disparities in access to hepatitis C therapies. The study analyzed data from Quest Diagnostics and found that only one in three Americans diagnosed with hepatitis C were cured over the past decade. Cure rates varied depending on factors such as age and insurance coverage, with younger patients and those with little or no insurance being less likely to be cured compared to older patients and those with better insurance coverage.

The study also revealed that the demographics of hepatitis C infections have shifted, with adults under 40 now being the group most likely to be infected. This increase is primarily driven by the rise in injected drug use. The low cure rates and increasing number of cases highlight the need for improved access to treatment and better awareness of the disease.

Despite efforts to increase screening and testing for hepatitis C, many doctors and patients are still unaware of the recommendations. The testing process itself can be complicated and time-consuming, leading to delays in diagnosis and treatment initiation. The cost of treatment remains a significant barrier, even though prices have come down to around $24,000 for a course of treatment in the US. However, in countries like Egypt, the cost has been significantly reduced to $85 per person by authorizing generic versions of the drugs.

The high cost of treatment has resulted in insurance plans implementing barriers to access, such as requiring proof of liver damage or sobriety before covering the drugs. These requirements go against national treatment recommendations and impede timely access to care. Efforts to negotiate subscription services with drug companies, known as the "Netflix model," have been successful in some states and have expanded access to treatment. However, implementing such models nationwide will require significant investment and political will.

Addressing the barriers to hepatitis C treatment is crucial to prevent further liver damage, transmission of the infection, and related complications like liver failure and liver cancer. Advocacy for affordable and accessible treatment options, improved awareness and education, and policy changes are necessary to eliminate the disparities in hepatitis C care and achieve the goal of eliminating the disease by 2030.

The Biden administration has identified fentanyl laced with xylazine, an animal sedative known as "tranq," as an emerging threat in the United States. A new analysis of toxicology reports reveals a significant increase in the presence of xylazine in fentanyl overdose deaths. In June 2022, xylazine was detected in nearly 11% of fentanyl overdose deaths, compared to about 3% in January 2019.

The data, published by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), is based on a subset of states that participated in the CDC's State Unintentional Drug Overdose Reporting System. The researchers acknowledge that reporting practices have varied, and increased prevalence may partially reflect greater awareness and testing. However, consistent testing for xylazine is needed to understand the true extent of the issue.

Xylazine is not an opioid but is used as a tranquilizer in veterinary medicine. It is not approved for use in humans and can cause severe damage, including skin ulcers, soft-tissue wounds, and necrosis. The reason behind the tissue wounds caused by xylazine is not yet understood, but experts suggest that additives in the drugs may contribute to these effects.

The report indicates that fatal fentanyl overdoses, with or without xylazine, share similar circumstances and characteristics. Naloxone, the overdose-reversal medication, is not effective for xylazine overdoses since it is not an opioid. However, naloxone was administered in about a quarter of cases involving xylazine. When xylazine was not present, individuals were more likely to have no pulse by the time first responders arrived.

The majority of fentanyl overdoses involving xylazine occurred in the Northeast, particularly in Maryland, Connecticut, and Pennsylvania. In these states, xylazine was present in about a quarter of all fentanyl overdose deaths, twice the national rate. The prevalence of xylazine in fentanyl varied depending on the region and the form of the drug seized.

Further investigation is needed to understand the effects of xylazine on humans and why it is sought out in drug use. Clinicians are currently providing naloxone and oxygenation as immediate interventions, but additional treatment options are being explored. The rise of xylazine in fentanyl-related deaths highlights the need for prevention strategies and further research to address this emerging threat.

The United States is experiencing a particularly severe tick season, leading experts to emphasize the importance of personal precautions to prevent tick-borne diseases. Diagnoses of Lyme disease, a bacterial infection transmitted by blacklegged ticks or deer ticks, were 17% higher in the first week of June compared to the previous year. The data, collected by athenahealth, represents a significant increase in the past three weeks, with the seasonal peak expected to occur just before the Fourth of July holiday.

Ticks, particularly blacklegged ticks, are considered a significant public health threat as they can transmit various diseases to humans. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) tracks multiple species of ticks and at least seven pathogens they can spread. Cases of babesiosis, another tick-borne disease that can be fatal, have also been on the rise, growing 25% from 2011 to 2019.

Several factors contribute to the increased risk of tick-borne diseases. The habitat of ticks, including blacklegged ticks and Lone Star ticks, is expanding further into the Northeast, Midwest, and Middle Atlantic states. Additionally, changing human habitats, such as reforestation and population movement into tick-prone areas, create environments suitable for tick hosts. Warmer weather also extends the tick lifecycle, increasing their opportunities to find hosts and spread diseases.

The nymph stage of the blacklegged tick, which occurs from late May to early July, poses a particular risk to humans. Nymph ticks, as small as a poppy seed, may already be carrying diseases from their previous hosts. Increased awareness of tick-borne diseases may contribute to the rise in Lyme disease diagnoses. Experts urge both doctors and patients to be vigilant and pay attention to symptoms, which can include fever, headache, and joint pain.

Controlling the tick population is challenging, making personal precautions crucial. Tick prevention measures, such as wearing protective clothing, using tick repellents, and checking for ticks after potential exposure, are recommended. Prompt removal of ticks within the first 24 hours of attachment is crucial to reduce the risk of disease transmission.

Public health officials in Texas and Florida have reported no new cases of locally acquired malaria following a national alert. The Texas Department of State Health Services is aware of only one case in the state, and no infected mosquitoes have been found. Similarly, the Florida Department of Health has not reported any new cases, and all four individuals previously diagnosed with malaria have recovered.

Malaria is typically imported into the United States when someone travels to a country where the disease is more prevalent. However, these recent cases mark the first instances of locally acquired malaria in the US in the past 20 years. The Texas case involved an individual who did not have recent overseas travel history but had been working outdoors in Cameron County.

Both state health departments are actively monitoring the situation, conducting mosquito surveillance, and coordinating with local health departments. The Florida Department of Health has issued advisories and reminders for the public to take precautions against mosquito bites, especially during the Fourth of July holiday.

The US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) emphasizes that the risk of locally acquired malaria in the US remains extremely low. The CDC is collaborating with health departments in Florida and Texas to investigate these cases but has found no evidence linking them. The agency advises against testing mosquitoes for Plasmodium outside the affected areas, as there is no indication of higher risk in other regions.

A new report from the nonprofit organization Truth Initiative reveals that residents of 12 states in the South and Midwest, referred to as "Tobacco Nation," are more likely to smoke and smoke more heavily compared to individuals in the rest of the United States. These states include Alabama, Arkansas, Indiana, Kentucky, Louisiana, Michigan, Mississippi, Missouri, Ohio, Oklahoma, Tennessee, and West Virginia.

Despite comprising only 21% of the US population, Tobacco Nation is home to 28% of the country's smokers. The prevalence of smoking in these states is approximately 50% higher than the national average, with 19% of adults smoking compared to 13% in other states. This pattern is also observed among young adults, where 11% in Tobacco Nation smoke compared to less than 8% in other states. Additionally, teenagers in these states have a higher likelihood of smoking.

The report highlights weaker local policies on tobacco prevention and cessation in Tobacco Nation as a significant factor contributing to the disparity. The influence of the tobacco industry and lack of political will from decision-makers play a role in these states' limited efforts to address smoking prevalence. For instance, while federal data indicates a historic low in adult smoking rates, e-cigarette usage has increased in popularity. While hundreds of local governments across the country have enacted laws restricting the sale of flavored tobacco, only three of those measures have been implemented in the 12 states with higher smoking prevalence.

Moreover, the report reveals that smokers in Tobacco Nation consume significantly more cigarettes than smokers in other states. On average, an individual in Tobacco Nation consumes approximately 53 packs per year, compared to an average of 29 packs in the rest of the US, amounting to around 500 more cigarettes per person annually.

Tobacco use is the leading cause of preventable disease, disability, and death in the United States, according to the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Smoking and exposure to secondhand smoke lead to nearly half a million premature deaths annually and cause severe illnesses in millions more.

The report emphasizes the importance of implementing stronger actions and policies to address these geographic disparities, improve public health, and promote smoke-free lives in Tobacco Nation. It underscores the negative impact of tobacco use, including shorter life expectancy, worse health indicators, and higher tobacco use rates in these states.

A new case of HIV has been linked to a "vampire facial" procedure at an Albuquerque spa that closed in 2018, according to the New Mexico Department of Health. The patient reported that the only potential HIV risk was the vampire facial received at VIP Beauty Salon and Spa in 2018. Two previous cases of HIV were also associated with injection-related procedures at the same spa in 2019. In response, the Department of Health has reopened its investigation into the spa and is recommending that former clients who received injection-related services, such as vampire facials or Botox, undergo testing for HIV, hepatitis B, and hepatitis C. The state health department previously conducted testing for over 100 spa clients during the initial investigation, and it advises former clients to be retested even if they previously tested negative. The spa had been closed in 2018 due to unsafe practices that could potentially spread blood-borne infections. The owner of the spa pleaded guilty to five felony counts of practicing medicine without a license in June 2022. A vampire facial involves injecting plasma, typically derived from the patient's own blood, into the skin using a micro-needling pen. Infections can occur if there is reuse of micro-needling tips or syringes or if another patient's blood is used during the procedure.

Mark Cavendish is out of the Tour de France after crashing during stage eight on Saturday.

The Manxman, 38, had already said this Tour would be his last as he plans to retire at the end of the season.

Widely regarded as cycling's greatest sprinter of all time, Cavendish came into this year's Tour level on 34 stage wins with Belgian legend Eddy Merckx.

Jasper Philipsen denied Cavendish a record breaking 35th stage win during stage seven on Friday.

Cavendish was involved in an innocuous crash with Pello Bilbao 60km from the finish of Saturday's 200.7km transitional stage between Libourne and Limoges.

He suffered a suspected broken collarbone and went into an ambulance, with his team Astana Qazaqstan confirming he was forced to abandon the race.

The Tour added Heartbreaking for the Manx Missile. 

Cavendish is the fifth rider to abandon this year's Tour after Enric Mas, Richard Carapaz, Jacopo Guarnieri and Luis Leon Sanchez, with all those withdrawals due to crashes.

It marks the seventh time from 14 appearances that Cavendish, who made his Tour debut in 2007, has not finished the race.

After a two year absence, and having not won a Tour stage since 2016, he returned in 2021 to win four and move level with five time Tour winner Merckx.

Lee Carsley has urged his England Under 21 side to take their chance at European Championship glory because his players can't get this time back after their final against Spain on Saturday.

The match at Georgia's Batumi Arena marks the end of a two year cycle for Carsley's side, with many of his players no longer eligible to play U21 football once the final whistle blows.

 We've spoken about this literally being a moment in time and that it's going to pass quickly, said Carsley.

 It's making the most of now and trying to encourage them that they can't get this time back. Whether we've done well or not, this time we've had now, we're not going to get it back.

 It's about trying to remove the pressure and let them enjoy the experience.

 I always think that if you give the players that feeling of responsibility and ownership, then they are more than likely to perform because they feel part of what we're trying to do. 

England U21s on brink of first Euros win since 1984
James Trafford From farm to the final, is this England's future number one?
How did England's 1984 winners do afterwards?
The Young Lions have been widely praised for the exciting football they have played during this tournament.

England are also yet to concede a goal in the competition and the possibility of winning the trophy has started a discussion about how this could be one of the best generations of young players to come through the English pathway.

 I think the fact that they've got this far in the tournament would suggest that, said Carsley.

 It's three age groups coming together the previous 21s, the 20s and some of the 19s. So creating a good atmosphere and dynamic within that squad and their personalities was important.

 A lot of them are vying for the same position and have played against each other for a while now. So it's about getting that mix right. 

'I don't see this as a beginning, middle or end'
Carsley's own future has been a talking point heading into this tournament, with the 50 year old on a rolling contract and ongoing speculation he could leave his role at the end of the Championships.

 I don't see this as a beginning, middle or end, he said.

 It was more important for me that the players had a really good experience that was the biggest thing.

 I don't see this as a step to somewhere else. I see this as making sure I can do a good job, and being as well prepared as I can be. I tried three or four years ago not to look too far ahead on what's next I did as a player, massively, I was always constantly thinking about it.

 I try to avoid that as a coach. I'm not looking at these players as a springboard the opposite to that. The most important thing to me is they perform well in the final and show what they can do. 

If England do manage to beat Spain, it would be the first time the Young Lions have won this competition since 1984.

 The team have got maybe two or three levels to go, said Carsley. If they click it'll be a hell of a performance tomorrow.

 The bigger the stage you'll see a different intensity to the team. I'm looking forward to it.

Whenever Andy Murray waves goodbye to Centre Court these days, nobody can confidently predict if it will be the last time or not.

In the hours after another disheartening defeat in the second round at Wimbledon, even the 36 year old was unsure.

At the start of the 10th anniversary of Murray's iconic first title at the All England Club, when he ended Britain's 77 year wait for a men's singles champion, there was hope.

The hope was that he could complete a memorable win over Greek fifth seed Stefanos Tsitsipas and earn his most notable victory at a Grand Slam since having career saving hip surgery in 2019.

By the end of the day, the former world number one questioned whether all the effort, pain and sacrifice of trying to go deep at Wimbledon was worth repeating.

Asked if he was confident of returning next year, Murray said: I don't know. Motivation is obviously a big thing.

 Continuing having early losses in tournaments like this doesn't necessarily help with that. 

Murray cut a forlorn figure as he spoke to journalists, looking incredibly downbeat as he dissected his five set defeat by 24 year old Tsitsipas.

The scene was nothing new. Revealing raw emotion after difficult defeats at the place where he puts the greatest emphasis on winning has been common in the past few years.

In 2021, Murray said he needed to weigh up if all the hard work is worth it after an encouraging run was ended by Canada's Denis Shapovalov in the third round.

In 2022, an equally despondent Murray also questioned his future after suffering his earliest exit at Wimbledon at the hands of American John Isner in the second round.

This year, for all the bullish talk in the build up, the tournament ended with the same result.

 Losing in the second round, I don't find that motivating. It's not why I put all of the work in, said Murray, who has not reached the fourth round of a major since Wimbledon in 2017.

 It's similar to last year, I guess. I had a long think about things, spoke to my family, and decided to keep on going.

 I'm unbelievably disappointed and upset now. Maybe I will feel different in a few days but right now it doesn't feel good. 

This summer, Murray has channelled all his efforts into a deep run at the place where he has won two of his three major titles.

That is what makes the disappointment even harder to take.

Murray decided to skip the clay court French Open, preferring instead to start his preparations on the British grass on which he thrives.

Dropping down to the ATP Challenger Tour the level below the main tour led to title wins in Surbiton and Nottingham.

Murray suffered a chastening defeat against Alex de Minaur when he made the step up in class at Queen's. Nothing to panic about, he insisted.

But, crucially, it meant he missed out on a seeding and left him open to the prospect of facing one of the highest ranked players in the first two rounds.

The draw threw up a potential second round match against Tsitsipas a two time major finalist tipped to win one of the sport's biggest prizes sooner rather than later.

When that highly anticipated meeting panned out, Murray stepped up to the occasion as he regularly does on the big stage and showed glimpses of his best.

It was testament to his performance that Tsitsipas had to produce his best display on grass in a long time to pull through.

Not even that could soften the blow for Murray, who knows he can still mix it with the world's best.

 I certainly can. It's clear based on how the match went. There was only a few points in it, he said.

 But it's not just about winning the odd match against them really. To have a run at these tournaments, you need multiple, multiple wins in a row. I've not done that. 

Murray is not the type of player to rush into any major decisions and his love for the game is evident by the depths from which he has recovered to continue playing.

Last weekend, Murray said he had an idea in my head about when he wanted to retire. That decision does not look imminent but the scars of this latest Wimbledon loss may lead to reassessment.

Tim Henman, Murray's former Davis Cup team mate and long time friend, believes the Scot will reflect more positively when the dust is settled .

 Andy has got a wise head on slightly older shoulders now and he is absolutely right not to commit to anything, he said.

 He will reflect on how much effort he has put in this year. He dropped down levels to play in Challenger events and to win two on grass. That emphasises the hunger and desire.

 That desire still burns bright and I really hope there is more to come for Andy.

Former Manchester United and Ajax goalkeeper Edwin van der Sar's condition is stable but still concerning following a bleed on his brain, his family says.

The 52 year old was taken to an intensive care unit on Friday.

He will remain in intensive care for the time being said Ajax in a statement on behalf of his wife.

He is reportedly being treated in a hospital in Croatia, where he was on holiday.

The former Netherlands international, who won 130 caps for his country, resigned from his role as Ajax chief executive in May after the side finished third in the Dutch league and failed to qualify for the Champions League for the first time since 2009.

He retired from playing after leaving United in 2011 before joining the Ajax board in 2012, and later becoming the club's chief executive in 2016.

Van der Sar made 266 appearances for the Red Devils and helped them to win four Premier League titles and the 2008 Champions League.

He also played in the Premier League for Fulham and in Serie A for Juventus.

His former clubs and teammates are among those sending their support to Van der Sar.

The Van der Sar family, along with Ajax, is grateful and deeply touched by the many messages of support, Ajax said.

Football world rooting for Van der Sar analysis
Simon Stone, BBC Sport's senior football reporter

Football is united in hoping Van der Sar makes a full recovery.

First as a superb goalkeeper with Ajax, Juventus, Fulham and Manchester United, plus the Dutch national team then as an administrator, at Ajax and with the influential European Clubs' Association, he has developed a first rate reputation.

I spoke to him in Istanbul, on the day of last month's Champions League final, when he talked about Andre Onana's likely influence on the game, Erik ten Hag's time at Manchester United and also his future plans.

Van der Sar endured a difficult final season with Ajax but, despite leaving the club, gave the impression of someone not intent on staying out of the game for long.

Through the recovery of his wife Annemarie, who suffered a brain haemorrhage when he was a player at United in 2009 and Sir Alex Ferguson, who collapsed in 2018, there are positive examples to reflect on in this uncertain time.

Football is worried on Van der Sar's behalf. There are many good wishes being extended in public and private as it absorbs this news.

A raft of England's finest former youth players are set to walk out on to the world stage this month, but not all will represent the Lionesses. Some will play for the land of their parents or grandparents after opting to switch sporting nationality.

BBC Sport has spoken to Tottenham pair Rosella Ayane and Becky Spencer and Leicester City's Ashleigh Plumptre about that bold decision and its consequences.

Part of the family
When Morocco secured their first ever Women's World Cup place last year, Spurs forward Ayane had to get on a chair and make good on an earlier promise.

The first English player from the Women's Super League to represent the Atlas Lionesses, she had changed sporting allegiance from England the year before but was yet to perform her initiation song.

Pressed to deliver at the start of the Women's Africa Cup of Nations (Afcon), Ayane had put her new teammates off, insisting they grab that World Cup ticket with a top four finish first.

 They didn't forget, she laughs. The minute we got into the hotel after we'd qualified, they made me stand up on the chair and I sang my little heart out.

 I picked an Adele song that everyone knew and they embraced it, they joined in and it showed how much they want me to be a part of that family. 

Rosella Ayane playing for England Under 19s in 2013
Rosella Ayane played for England at under 17 and under 19 level
Born in Reading to a Scottish mum and Moroccan dad, 27 year old Ayane was raised in England's youth system alongside current Lionesses Leah Williamson and Katie Zelem.

But with no senior caps by 2021, and with Morocco having twice reached out, she chose to fulfill her still burning international ambitions with the Atlas Lionesses.

 I was very honored, she says. And not only did it feel right football wise, it felt right mentally for the place I was at. 

Unable to speak French or Arabic and knowing neither the players nor head coach Reynald Pedros, her switch was, nevertheless, a step outside her comfort zone.

 I really respect the way they've taken me in, she says. I'm from a completely different culture, speak a completely different language and it would be quite easy for them to isolate me, but they do the exact opposite. 

Rosella Ayane celebrates during Morocco's semifinal with Nigeria
Rosella Ayane scored the winning penalty to send Morocco into the Afcon final
Ayane repaid them by letting her football do the talking her crucial winning spot kick against Nigeria took the Atlas Lionesses to their first Afcon final and she netted again in the 2 1 loss to South Africa in the showpiece.

In May, she won a Moroccans of the World award for her sporting exploits and, with a World Cup in the offing, her decision to switch is a personal triumph.

Yet looking back on a campaign during which thousands of Moroccans took the players to their hearts, Ayane sees a bigger picture.

 I think we are starting to change the dynamic, the respect and the view of women's football in Morocco, she says. If we can change the perspective of a country and help inspire the next generation, that for me is an achievement I'll be forever proud of. 

Jamaica accept me for who I am
Londoner Spencer, whose dad is Jamaican, also switched from England in 2021 and the move has revitalized her.

 I had toyed with retiring before this, says the 32 year old Tottenham keeper. Now I've picked it back up and it's motivated me again to go on for a few more years. 

A Champions League winner with Arsenal in 2007, Spencer has long been a familiar face in the top flight and has made more than 100 WSL appearances.

She was England's number one at the 2008 Under 20 Women's World Cup, and the following year was unbeaten in their tournament victory at the Under 19 European Championship alongside Lucy Bronze, Laura Coombs, Jordan Nobbs and Demi Stokes.

Senior call ups followed but Spencer remained uncapped so concentrated on her club form and media work instead.

 I didn't think about it and I wasn't missing it, she says. I was actually quite exhausted because when you do that from such a young age you don't know any different. 

An approach from Jamaica reignited her interest though and, after keeping a clean sheet on her debut against Nigeria in 2021, the WSL stalwart felt accepted by the Reggae Girlz for who I was and the player that I am .

Becky Spencer playing for Jamaica
Becky Spencer says the decision to play for Jamaica has motivated her to continue her career
Two head coaches have departed Jamaica since, and the players recently criticized their federation for its subpar support before this World Cup.

Speaking prior to that, Spencer said: There's not a lot of money in that federation so with that you don't know what to expect, but we've got a very good core of players that stick together. 

Among them is Spurs midfielder Drew Spence, 30, who also switched from England, and the two friends contributed to the victories that secured Jamaica's return to the world stage.

Now Spencer hopes the team's visibility at this World Cup will inspire Jamaica's future players and their nation.

 They love us over there, she adds. So we hope we can do them proud. 

A journey to self understanding
Leicester City defender Plumptre will never forget her debut for Nigeria against Ivory Coast in 2022. Returning to her hotel afterward, she burst into tears.

 I'd been holding so much emotion back for so long, she says. This was something I'd been waiting to do for a long time and it was huge for my family. 

It was also a big moment for former England youth player Plumptre, who had changed sporting nationality to the birthplace of her grandfather the previous year.

 I had a lot of people questioning why I chose Nigeria over England, she says. Playing with Nigeria is part of this journey that I'm on. It's not necessarily football, it's a life journey. 

'People always assume I'm white' Plumptre
Ashleigh Plumptre celebrates a win with Nigeria
Ashleigh Plumptre helped Nigeria to a 2 0 win over Ivory Coast on her debut
Born in Leicester, 25 year old Plumptre enjoyed great experiences with England in two European Under 17 Championships alongside future Euro 2022 stars Chloe Kelly and Alessia Russo.

But she started to consider her connections to Nigeria after frank lockdown chats with her younger half sister about racism, their African heritage, and a culture neither really knew.

Reaching out to the Super Falcons was her next step, although Plumptre was initially so overawed by her teammates she got off the bus without daring to speak to Barcelona's star striker Asisat Oshoala.

Stepping up during a tricky Afcon campaign that saw Nigeria lose their continental crown but qualify for a ninth World Cup, the calm and composed defender earned the right to be among them out in Australia.

 This was something that was never an aim of mine when I first joined Nigeria, she says. But being on the qualifying journey with the team to get here has taught me so much and given me amazing life experiences.

A big hitter, with an aggressive game built around her forehand, Boulter is a popular player with the home fans and is the only Briton left in either singles draw following the exits of Andy Murray, Cameron Norrie and Liam Broady on Friday.

Boulter claimed an emotional victory over former world number one Pliskova on Centre Court last year and is aiming to channel those memories against Rybakina.

 I still think about the time that I served it out. That's something that I draw on.

 I'm already excited to play against a top player and have a go. I think they're the moments I get excited for.

A more subdued figure on court than Boulter, the Australian Open runner up is not worried about the home crowd support her opponent will receive.

 She's a tough player and her game is aggressive. It's going to be a tough one.

The Serb dominated the opening two sets, winning them in a total of 67 minutes, dropping only four games while doing so, but Warwrinka produced a better performance in the third set.
Djokovic, who is aiming to equal Roger Federer's men's record of eight titles, ensured his match would not go into extra time as he fought back from 5 3 down in the tie break to advance into the last 16.
 We are two old guys fighting with the young guns, said Djokovic. We have had some amazing battles on the biggest courts. I respect him as a player and he is a really nice guy so I wish him all the best for the rest of the season.
 He was only two points away from extending the match to another day. One of us had to win in straight sets [for it to end on Friday] and it looked very good in the first two sets.
 He then raised his level and I dropped mine, the crowd got involved and it was a good atmosphere.
 I know I have a couple of gears that I can go to as the tournament progresses. 
This is Alcaraz's third year of playing at Wimbledon and in 2021 he won on court six, before losing on Court One. His three wins in 2022 included two victories on Court One and another success on court two ahead before losing to Jannik Sinner in the last 16 on Centre Court.

 It's something I wanted to enjoy every single second of and I did, said Alcaraz. I'm playing at a great level, getting more experience and getting better each match.

The Spaniard showing superb touch, technique and pace of shot gained the vital break in the seventh game.
Alcaraz won the tie break and was untroubled in the third set to set up a meeting with 25th seed Nicolas Jarry of Chile in round three.
Earlier this week, Medvedev, who has never gone past the last 16 at Wimbledon, said he didn't feel at home on grass, and now said: I'm getting there. Maybe at the door. Not inside, but at the door.

Ben Stokes provided yet more heroics and his bowlers crucial late wickets as England desperately battled to keep their Ashes hopes alive on day two of the third Test at Headingley. Stokes' knock meant the tourists' first innings lead was just 26, despite four wickets falling in the morning session including Joe Root with the second ball of the day to Pat Cummins, who claimed 6 91.

The England captain attacked after lunch, launching five sixes and six fours, while Mark Wood helped swing the momentum with 24 from eight balls.

In reply, despite the loss of David Warner for one, the opener again caught off Stuart Broad, Australia eased to 68 1 and a lead of 94 as they threatened to take a firm grip on an enthralling Test.

But Moeen Ali removed Marnus Labuschagne and Steve Smith in successive overs before Chris Woakes dismissed Usman Khawaja in the final hour for 43.

Travis Head and first innings centurion Mitchell Marsh survived the final 45 minutes to leave the Test, in which a win would seal the series for Australia, finely poised.

England are already attempting to do what they have never done before overturn a 2 0 deficit to win the Ashes and at times on a captivating second day their hopes were fading.

But in Stokes they have a player at his best when his back is against the wall, shown in his incredible 155 in last week's second Test defeat and in his iconic, match winning 135 not out at Headingley in 2019.

England resumed on 68 3 but by lunch they had just three wickets left and were still 121 runs in arrears, only for their captain to almost drag them to parity all while struggling with a glute injury.

That injury prevented Stokes from bowling and, with Ollie Robinson also out of the attack with a back spasm, England were struggling when Khawaja and Labuschagne blunted the new ball.

England stuck to their task, though, on a pitch offering less movement and pace than on day one.

The presence of Marsh and Head, two batters who can score quickly, is a danger, but Headingley is the best Test ground in England to bat in the fourth innings.

In the past three fourth innings chases at the ground 359, 322 and 296 have been made to win, while Leicestershire knocked off 389 here in county cricket earlier this summer.

Stokes fights through the pain

Stokes arrived at the crease when Root got a ball from Cummins that bounced, took the edge and was snaffled by Warner at first slip.

Within the first half hour, Bairstow edged a full ball to Smith from Mitchell Starc when attempting a slashing drive.

Stokes was patient in the morning session, sharing watchful partnership of 44 until Moeen fell into the short ball trap and was caught at fine leg for 19.

The England captain watched from the non striker's end as Woakes was hit on the head by a Starc bouncer, responded by a clubbing another for six but was then inevitably caught behind on the pull via a thin edge.

Wood was the unlikely instigator of England's counter attack. He smacked Starc for six first ball and cleared the rope twice more in eight balls before Stokes flicked the switch.

Again he hogged the strike to put on 32 with number 10 Broad and 38 with last man Robinson as he smashed Ashes debutant Todd Murphy for five sixes, including one huge straight hit into the top tier.

Stokes offered two tough chances in successive balls while on 45 Starc spilling a running catch from long off and spinner Murphy a caught and bowled but was finally dismissed after slicing another heave into the hands of Smith at long on.

Labuschagne & Smith hand England opening

The rate at which England lost wickets and scored runs meant their bowlers had little more than 50 overs of rest before taking to the field again, the injuries only adding to their woe.

But the early boost came when Warner nicked Broad to second slip, the 17th time he has been dismissed by the England seamer in Tests, to leave Australia 11 1.

On 33, Labuschagne offered a chance down the leg side when attempting to pull Wood but, diving one handed, Bairstow spilled his third chance of the match.

England's wicketkeeper would have been relieved when the right hander slog swept his next ball straight into the hands of Harry Brook at deep mid wicket.

If that wicket was an unexpected gift, the next was even more so. Smith, usually immovable, simply clipped Moeen to mid wicket to hand England's off spinner his 200th Test scalp Bairstow sending Smith on his way with a word from behind the stumps.

Wood, who bowled quickly again but slightly slower than on day one, looked exhausted when he made way after a testing spell.

He was replaced by Woakes, who tempted Khawaja into a poke for a crucial late breakthrough courtesy of a decent edge through to Bairstow.

That put England on top but Marsh, more restrained than in the first innings, and left hander Head ensured the Test remains perfectly in the balance.

'A tremendous battle' reaction

BBC cricket correspondent Jonathan Agnew on Test Match Special: A fascinating game of cricket, all the players out there have given absolutely everything and it has been a tremendous battle.

 Can England keep the Ashes alive? At the moment, it's well within their grasp. 

England all rounder Moeen Ali: I'm really glad I came back to Test cricket. Playing under Stokes and Brendon even when bowling I don't feel under pressure. The environment is my sort of environment for sure. 

Former England captain Michael Vaughan: It's fantastic to watch, you just don't know which way it is going to sway.

 Ben Stokes is just remarkable whilst there was carnage around him he just had clarity. 

Australia captain Pat Cummins: I'm sure the fans are loving it but I wouldn't mind a stress free day or two. It's all set up for another wonderful match.

Great Britain's Jazmin Sawyers, who won her first major long jump title at the European indoors in March, will feature in a series of BBC Sport columns in the build up to August's World Athletics Championships in Budapest.

In her second piece, Jazz discusses the need for more women specific sport science research, which could prove career altering for elite athletes and prevent young girls from giving up sport altogether.

Women's sport is growing rapidly in popularity but the science is still lagging behind only about 6% of sports science research is conducted exclusively on female athletes.

As athletes, we automatically jump to the decision that we're not good enough after a poor performance, rather than stopping to consider what is going on inside our own bodies.

The public do the same thing, because that's the norm. It's the way we treat sportspeople in general. The conversation is often around how an athlete failed to handle the occasion when, sometimes, there's a physiological issue.

For me, managing your body is easily one of the hardest aspects of being a female athlete. But this is a conversation for everyone.

After pulling up with cramps at last year's European Championships, 2019 200m world champion Dina Asher Smith called for more research into the effect of periods on performance.

It would be career altering for sportswomen if we knew more.

I would love to see more research about the effects of the menstrual cycle, which could inform how we train, help us to avoid preventable injuries, and teach us how to optimize our performances at major championships.

Women can track their own symptoms, monitor how they feel, try to predict where in the month they can push themselves and when they need to hold back.

But these are things we, as women in the world of professional sport, are still having to figure out for ourselves.

As elite athletes, although we can't influence the level of research being undertaken, what we can do is talk openly about the topic and do our bit to normalize the conversation.

Pain and panic filled the hours before my Olympic debut

In 2017 I was forced to pull out of a competition in Boston because my period pain was so severe. I talked a little bit about it and I was shocked when it became a news story.

It clicked then that this was a conversation we need to have because it shouldn't be a big deal.

To me, it was an important piece of the puzzle to figure out because I didn't feel like I should be that far into my professional career and still have such little knowledge about my cycle.

I wasn't supposed to be coming on my period that day and I physically wasn't able to compete. With better education, I may have been prepared for that situation.

A year earlier, four hours before qualifying began at my first Olympic Games, I was in the doctor's room screaming in pain.

Despite putting a plan in place, testing medication throughout the year to delay my period and allow me to compete unhindered, it had started. I was immobile from the pain and I didn't know what the solution was.

It was pure panic. I thought my Olympic debut was over because I simply couldn't move from the bed.

Eventually I ended up just having a lot of painkillers and I scraped through to the final.

That really shouldn't be the solution.

I now have much better strategies, but it has taken seven years since that day for me to have a fully comprehensive plan to handle the issues my period brings.

By having these conversations with young athletes, making sure they get to know their cycle and that they feel comfortable speaking to coaches and sports doctors, hopefully, incidents like that will occur less frequently in elite sport.

Let's normalize the conversation and end the shame

Another disappointing statistic is that period pain and shame are key reasons why 64% of schoolgirls will drop out of sport.

When I was a teenager, I wouldn't have dared to speak to my male coaches about my period. That was a shame thing, and it was to my detriment. It meant I didn't get the help I needed for so much longer.

It was preventable. We should be able to have those conversations. If more than half of young girls are dropping out because of period issues, then clearly, we have a problem.

We're still not comfortable enough in speaking about it. It needs to become as normal as discussing an injury.

Sport is such a force for good, and if something is proving such a barrier to young women staying in sport, we need to consider it a serious issue.

In families, in coaching situations, let's normalize talking about periods and how your menstrual cycle affects you and your training.

For women my age, we can be making more of an effort to learn about our own cycles. There's only so much we can talk about it if we don't understand ourselves.

A little more education can go a long way. Even at a recreational level, we could prevent someone who is trying to improve their 5k each week from becoming disheartened simply because they can't appreciate that their body isn't capable of a certain time that week.

The fact that periods have an effect on training and on our lives is something we must talk about as though it's normal.

On Saturday, the pair will represent their country on the biggest stage as they fight for titles during International Fight Week at UFC 290 in Las Vegas, Nevada.

Interim featherweight champion Rodriguez, 30, faces title holder Alexander Volkanovski in the main event for the undisputed belt. Moreno, 29, defends his flyweight championship against Alexandre Pantoja in the co main.

On the undercard, there are three more Mexican fighters Yazmin Jauregui, Edgar Chairez, and Jesus Aguilar.

 It's a real special card now, I'm happy for everybody. Rodriguez told BBC Sport. Everybody is achieving their dreams to become UFC fighters.

 Now we're showing the world what we're capable of doing. It couldn't make me happier. 

Two years ago, Moreno beat Deiveson Figueiredo to become the first Mexican born champion in UFC history. In February, Rodriguez defeated Josh Emmett for the interim featherweight belt.

Less than a month later, Alexa Grasso stunned fellow flyweight Valentina Shevchenko to become the first Mexican UFC women's champion.

The excitement around MMA is palpable in the country.

 When I go to my hometown, Tijuana, I remember when it was normal to go for a walk or a coffee, and now it's different, said Moreno.

 You can feel the support. Going to the capital of Mexico, you can feel the support. Before, a lot didn't know about MMA, and now they do. 

The UFC is capitalizing on the success of its Mexican stars.

The promotion is building a performance institute in the country to help develop fighters and recently announced a special event in recognition of Mexican Independence Day on 16 September when Grasso will defend her flyweight title in a rematch against Shevchenko.

UFC president Dana White said this week that each Mexican champion will receive a customized belt in the country's colors.

And Rodriguez says youngsters are now taking up MMA over other sports.

 People are bringing their little kids to gyms, said Rodriguez. Before you'd see boxing or karate or taekwondo but nothing like MMA. Now we've got little kids learning about the sport. I think we have a big future.

 Mexican fans are crazy about fighting. It doesn't matter what combat sport it is, they're crazy about it. 

Moreno echoes those thoughts.

 I always say the same I started this sport for myself. I just wanted to prove to myself I could go into the octagon and fight somebody, he said.

 But with all the success, you start to inspire people. I'm very happy when someone tells me this little kid is training because of me or they tag me in social posts. I motivate them, and that made me very proud.

Russell and teammate Lewis Hamilton were 12th and 15th fastest as they lagged more than a second behind Max Verstappen's pace setting Red Bull.

This was despite Mercedes introducing a new front wing, the latest in a series of recent car upgrades aimed at moving them closer to the front of the field.

Russell said the team had to try to understand their lack of pace.

Hamilton said: It's a tough car to drive and no matter what we do to set it up, it remains a tough car to drive. 

The seven time champion said he felt no improvement when changing from the medium to the theoretically faster soft tire.

 That shows that something's wrong, Hamilton said. We're missing something. And on the long run, it didn't seem too bad, so that's a positive at least.

 George is over here with the setup and I'm over here. He was saying I was thinking of coming over to where you are, but your lap time is slow. And I was like I was thinking of coming to where you are.

 We will work on it tonight and hopefully, we will come up with something for tomorrow. 

Hamilton's race simulation pace was more competitive. He was faster than the Ferrari of Carlos Sainz which was the second fastest on a single lap, just 0.022secs slower than Verstappen but still considerably slower than the world champion's Red Bull.

Russell said: Definitely not our finest Friday. Conditions will be different tomorrow. We need to try to get to the bottom of it.

 The pace in first practice was looking quite good on the medium tire. We thought we were right up there if we took the soft.

 But in P2, we were nowhere and we just need to try and understand that.

 We see a small trend that when the temperature is hotter, we seem to take a bit of a step backwards. We have some ideas why that is. 

Temperatures at Silverstone on Friday, when 120,000 spectators attended the track, were in the high 20Cs but are expected to drop a little for the weekend when rain also threatens.

Verstappen looked imperious, despite his small margin over Sainz, and his long run on a race fuel load was especially impressive.

The Dutchman's race simulation run was more than 0.5secs a lap on average quicker on the same soft tire than teammate Sergio Perez, with Sainz a little further behind.

Williams driver Alex Albon was an impressive third fastest, with teammate Logan Sargeant fifth behind Perez.

Lando Norris was 14th fastest in the upgraded McLaren that impressed so much last weekend in Austria.

Ferrari's Charles Leclerc did not get out in the session at all after the team discovered an electrical problem over the lunch break.

Fernando Alonso, third in the championship for Aston Martin, was only 10th fastest on single lap pace, with teammate Lance Stroll sixth, ahead of the Haas of Nico Hulkenberg, Pierre Gasly's Alpine, and McLaren's Oscar Piastri.

Piastri, an Australian who is in his debut season, has on his car for the first time the upgrade that Norris debuted in Austria, while Norris has those parts in addition to a new front wing.

A number of the drivers said that they were struggling for grip, especially in the first session, as they tried a new, more robust Pirelli tire construction for the first time.

Pirelli has introduced the tire to lessen the risk of failures at high speed tracks such as Silverstone. But despite what the company says is a stronger construction, the teams were told to run the tires at unusually high pressures 26.5 psi at the front and 23 psi at the rear.

This compares with 23 and 20 psi at the Austrian Grand Prix last weekend and 24 and 20 psi at the Spanish Grand Prix last month.

Sporting prowess is something Lisa Adams knows all about.
The 32 year old is the younger sister of double Olympic shot put champion Valerie Adams, who is also her coach, and her brother Steven plays in the NBA for the Memphis Grizzlies.

Lisa was diagnosed with a form of cerebral palsy as a youngster but after spells playing netball, basketball, and rugby and only started her Para athletics career in 2018.
Since then, she has made huge strides, winning gold at the 2019 World Championships in Dubai and following that with victory at the Tokyo Paralympics one of three gold medalists for her nation in the field events in Japan.
Hollie Arnold (Great Britain) F46 javelin
Arnold is bidding for her fifth world title in a row, but this could be her toughest challenge to date.
Arnold, who was born without her right forearm, is the most experienced female athlete on the British team having made her international debut at the Beijing Paralympics when she was only 14.
The 29 year old's first major title came at the 2013 Worlds in Lyon the last time the competition was held in France and she went on to claim her maiden Paralympic title in Rio.
